New Records: Yamamoto and Darvish were the first Japanese-born starting pitchers to square off in major league playoff history.
The Padres and Dodgers combined to retire 26 consecutive batters — the longest streak in a single game in postseason history.
Key Match Events: Yoshinobu Yamamoto outdueled Yu Darvish in a historic playoff matchup.
The Los Angeles Dodgers got home runs from Kiké Hernández and Teoscar Hernández to beat the San Diego Padres 2-0.
Yamamoto allowed two hits over five innings for the Dodgers.
Evan Phillips got five outs, fanning Profar and Machado in the seventh.
Alex Vesia whiffed rookie standout Jackson Merrill to end the inning.
Michael Kopech worked a perfect eighth inning.
Blake Treinen got three quick outs for his second save of the series.
Tatis grounded out to end the game as Kiké Hernández made the play.
Teoscar Hernández’s homer chased Darvish in the seventh and made it 2-0.
The Dodgers led 1-0 on the drive by Kiké Hernández with two outs in the second.
The Padres ended the series by not scoring since the second inning of Game 3.
Post-Match Reflections: Kiké Hernández: 'This showed a lot from us'
The Dodgers are headed to the NLCS for the 16th time overall and first since 2021.
The Padres head into the offseason with plenty of promise for next year.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers will play Pete Alonso and the New York Mets in the best-of-seven NLCS starting Sunday night in Los Angeles.
The Dodgers won a decisive Game 5 at home for the first time since taking a 1981 NL Division Series against Houston.
The Padres’ big hitters went bust with their season on the line.
San Diego went scoreless for the final 24 innings of the series.
The teams combined to score 43 runs in the first five games of the series.

The winner-take-all finale was a tense pitching affair in front of a sellout crowd of 53,183 that included Los Angeles Lakers superstar LeBron James and a Hollywood contingent of Brad Pitt, Rob Lowe, Bryan Cranston and Jimmy Kimmel.

Yamamoto successfully covered first base three times after inducing grounders, making it easier on All-Star first baseman Freddie Freeman, who started after missing Game 4 with a sprained right ankle.
Los Angeles staved off elimination in San Diego with an 8-0 victory in Game 4 to force the deciding game back home.
Fans tossing balls and trash on the field caused a 12-minute delay in a Game 2 loss.
The public-address announcer warned fans in the middle of the fifth Friday not to throw objects or go on the field.
